title: Troy Deeney listens to Abba and the Lighthouse Family before Watford games because it makes him angry
text:
Troy story Troy Deeney listens to Abba and the Lighthouse Family before Watford games because it makes him angry 
Vicarage Road skipper says off the pitch he has to bury the animal he becomes on the field By Sam Morgan 26th March 2017, 3:11 pm Updated: 26th March 2017, 3:12 pm Comments TROY DEENEY listens to Abba and the Lighthouse Family before Watford games – because it makes him angry. 
The Vicarage Road skipper says the tracks remind him of when he was younger and unleash his “angry person”. Reuters 4 Troy Deeney listens to the same playlist before every game 
Deeney has bagged nine goals so far this season and helped the Hornets to 14th in the table. 
But it is the memory of growing up with mum – who worked three jobs – and dad, and wanting to escape that life that fuels his rage. 
Deeney, who also puts on songs by James Brown and Aretha Franklin before kick-off, told the Mail on Sunday : “That angry person is still there and it’s difficult for me to bring him out but I have to bring him out to be who I am on the football pitch. 
“Then I have to contain him as soon as I get back to real life and bury him back inside me. Reuters The Watford striker says the particular songs remind him of his childhood Getty Images 4 Abba are a big hit with Troy Deeney before games 
“It’s the aggressive man in me, the man who just wants to win, win in any aspect of life. 
“That’s what makes me good at football but it also makes me an animal. 
“If you prod me, normally there’s a reaction. 
“The playlist brings me back to my childhood and makes me really angry. 
“It’s slow music but when I listen to it, I hear a song and I know that mum would be doing a particular chore at this point. 
“My mum is my best friend. Deeney famously spent ten months in prison after beating a man in Birmingham city centre in 2012. 
He maintains it was the best thing that ever happened to him - but that the anger he felt then it still inside him. 
He added: "The way I was brought up, I got caught up in a lot of things I shouldn't have got caught up in. 
"I am angry at it but at the same time it has made me who I am. 
"What I have learned from my psychologist is that all people contradict themselves. 
"We don't want any of the bad stuff to happen but we needed it to make us who we are now."
